questions.title: What is C++?
questions.answer: C++ is a general-purpose programming language that is an extension of the C programming language. It supports object-oriented, procedural, and generic programming paradigms and is widely used for system development, game development, and more.

questions.title: What is the difference between C and C++?
questions.answer: C++ is an extension of C with added features like classes and objects for object-oriented programming. C is a procedural language, while C++ supports both procedural and object-oriented programming.

questions.title: What is an object in C++?
questions.answer: An object in C++ is an instance of a class, which is a blueprint for creating objects. Objects encapsulate data (attributes) and behavior (methods) into a single unit.

questions.title: What is a class in C++?
questions.answer: A class in C++ is a user-defined data type that defines the structure and behavior of objects. It serves as a blueprint for creating objects with shared characteristics and behavior.

questions.title: What are constructors and destructors in C++?
questions.answer: Constructors are special member functions in C++ that are called when an object is created. Destructors are also special member functions that are called when an object is destroyed. Constructors initialize object attributes, while destructors clean up resources.

questions.title: What is the this pointer in C++?
questions.answer: The this pointer is a pointer that points to the current instance of an object. It is used to access object members within class methods when there is a naming conflict with local variables.

questions.title: Explain the differences between pass-by-value, pass-by-reference, and pass-by-pointer in function parameters.
questions.answer:
Pass-by-value makes a copy of the argument and operates on the copy.
Pass-by-reference uses references to the original object, allowing modifications to the original.
Pass-by-pointer uses pointers to the original object, similar to pass-by-reference.

questions.title: Discuss the differences between shallow copy and deep copy when copying objects in a programming language.
questions.answer:
Shallow copy creates a new object that is a copy of the original object, but it does not recursively duplicate objects contained within the original object. Changes made to nested objects in the copy affect the original.
Deep copy creates a new object and recursively duplicates all objects contained within the original object, ensuring that changes to nested objects in the copy do not affect the original.

questions.title: What is operator overloading in C++?
Describe the differences between stack and heap memory allocation in a programming language.
questions.answer:
Stack memory is used for function call management, local variables, and is managed automatically. It has limited and fixed size.
Heap memory is used for dynamic memory allocation, and you must manage it manually. It has a larger but variable size.

questions.title: What are virtual functions in C++?
questions.answer: Virtual functions are functions declared in a base class with the virtual keyword. They allow dynamic binding, enabling the selection of the appropriate function to call at runtime based on the object's actual type in a hierarchy of derived classes.

questions.title: What is the Standard Template Library (STL) in C++?
questions.answer: The STL is a collection of template classes and functions in C++ that provide common data structures (like vectors, lists, and maps) and algorithms (like sorting and searching) to simplify complex programming tasks.

questions.title: Explain RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization) in C++.
questions.answer: RAII is a C++ programming idiom where resource management (e.g., memory allocation, file handling) is tied to the lifespan of objects. Resources are acquired in the constructor and released in the destructor of objects, ensuring proper cleanup.

questions.title: What are the differences between the new operator and the malloc function in C++?
questions.answer: new is an operator in C++ used for dynamic memory allocation and calls constructors for class objects. malloc is a function in C that allocates memory without calling constructors. It's recommended to use new with C++ objects for proper initialization.

questions.title: Explain the concept of polymorphism in C++.
questions.answer: Polymorphism is the ability of objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common base class. It allows for generic programming and dynamic dispatch of functions based on the actual object type.

questions.title: What is a template in C++?
questions.answer: In C++, templates allow you to define generic types and functions that can work with different data types. They enable you to write reusable code that adapts to various data types.

questions.title: What is the role of the mutable keyword in C++?
Explain the Rule of Three in C++ and why it's important.
questions.answer: The Rule of Three states that if a class defines a custom destructor, copy constructor, or copy assignment operator, it should define all three. This ensures proper memory management and prevents issues like resource leaks or double deletion in custom classes.

questions.title: What is name hiding in C++?
questions.answer: Name hiding occurs when a derived class declares a member with the same name as a member in the base class. The derived class's member hides the base class's member in the scope of the derived class. To access the base class's member, you can use the scope resolution operator (::).

questions.title: Explain the use of const in C++ and its implications.
questions.answer: const is used to indicate that a variable, function parameter, or member function does not modify the data it refers to. It's used for creating constant values, preventing unintended modifications, and enabling compiler optimizations.

questions.title: What are the differences between the new and delete operators and the malloc and free functions for dynamic memory allocation?
questions.answer:
new and delete are C++ operators that handle dynamic memory allocation and deallocation, including calling constructors and destructors.
malloc and free are C functions that allocate and deallocate memory without constructor/destructor calls.

questions.title: Explain what the Rule of Five is in C++11 and later standards.
questions.answer:
The Rule of Five consists of five special member functions that should be defined when a class deals with resource management:
Destructor: Cleans up resources (e.g., memory) when an object is destroyed.
Copy Constructor: Creates a deep copy of an object when copied.
Copy Assignment Operator: Copies the contents of one object into another.
Move Constructor: Transfers ownership of resources from one object to another.
Move Assignment Operator: Transfers ownership of resources during assignment.

questions.title: Explain the purpose of the C++ Standard Library and provide examples of common containers and algorithms it provides.
questions.answer:
The C++ Standard Library is a collection of pre-defined classes, functions, and templates that provide commonly used data structures and algorithms.
Common containers include std::vector, std::map, std::set, and std::queue.
Common algorithms include std::sort, std::find, std::for_each, and std::accumulate.

questions.title: Explain the difference between const and constexpr in C++.
What is a lambda function in C++?
What are move semantics in C++? How do they improve performance?
What is the copy constructor, and when is it called?
questions.answer: The copy constructor is a special member function in C++ that is called when an object is copied. It creates a new object that is a copy of an existing object. It's automatically called in various situations, such as when passing objects by value, returning objects by value, or initializing new objects with existing ones.

questions.title: What is an abstract class in C++? How does it differ from an interface?
questions.answer:
An abstract class in C++ is a class that cannot be instantiated and often contains one or more pure virtual functions. Derived classes must implement these functions. It serves as a base class for other classes.
An interface in C++ is typically implemented using abstract classes with pure virtual functions. However, an interface only defines a contract (method signatures) that derived classes must adhere to. An abstract class can have some concrete implementation in addition to pure virtual functions.

questions.title: What is the use of the const_cast operator in C++?
questions.answer: The const_cast operator is used to add or remove the const qualifier from a pointer or reference. It's often used when you need to work with functions that take non-const pointers or when you need to modify data that was originally declared as const.

questions.title: Explain the purpose of the C++ Standard Library containers std::vector, std::list, and std::map.
questions.answer:
std::vector: A dynamic array that provides fast access to elements by index. It's suitable for scenarios where elements are frequently added or removed at the end.
std::list: A doubly-linked list that allows efficient insertions and deletions at any position but has slower random access compared to vectors.
std::map: A key-value associative container that allows efficient lookups by key. It's implemented as a binary search tree.

questions.title: What is SFINAE (Substitution Failure Is Not An Error) in C++?
questions.answer: SFINAE is a principle in C++ template metaprogramming where certain template instantiations are not considered errors during compilation but rather lead to template specialization. It's often used to enable or disable certain template instantiations based on the presence or absence of specific member functions or types.

questions.title: What is the use of std::move in C++?
questions.answer:
std::move is used to cast an object to an rvalue reference, indicating that the object can be moved from rather than copied. It's typically used in move semantics to efficiently transfer resources (e.g., memory ownership) from one object to another, reducing unnecessary copying.

typescript

Copy code

std::vector<int> source = {1, 2, 3};
std::vector<int> destination = std::move(source); // Move contents of source to destination

questions.title: Explain the purpose of the C++ Standard Library algorithms provided by the <algorithm> header.
questions.answer: The <algorithm> header provides a set of common algorithms for working with sequences, such as arrays, vectors, and other containers. These algorithms include sorting, searching, and manipulation functions that can be applied to a wide range of container types.

questions.title: What is an inline function in C++? Why is it used?
questions.answer: An inline function is a function that is expanded by the compiler at the call site, rather than being invoked through a regular function call. It's used to reduce function call overhead, especially for small and frequently called functions. It's typically implemented using the inline keyword.

questions.title: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using raw pointers in C++?
What is type erasure in C++?
questions.answer: Type erasure is a technique used to abstract the specific type of an object or value, allowing it to be treated uniformly, regardless of its actual type. It's often used to implement polymorphism without exposing the underlying types.

questions.title: What is the difference between a reference and a pointer in C++?
questions.answer:
A reference is an alias or an alternative name for an existing object. It cannot be reseated to refer to a different object after initialization and doesn't require dereferencing.
A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of an object. It can be reseated to point to different objects and requires explicit dereferencing using * operator.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the decltype keyword in C++?
questions.answer: The decltype keyword is used to deduce the type of an expression or variable at compile-time. It can be helpful when you want to declare a variable with the same type as another expression, especially in generic programming and template metaprogramming.

questions.title: What is function overloading in C++?
Explain the purpose of the std::mutex class in C++.
questions.answer: std::mutex is part of the C++ Standard Library and provides a mechanism for achieving mutual exclusion, allowing multiple threads to synchronize access to shared resources. It's commonly used to protect critical sections of code, preventing multiple threads from simultaneously modifying shared data, which can lead to data corruption or race conditions.

questions.title: What is CRTP (Curiously Recurring Template Pattern) in C++?
Explain what the Pimpl idiom (Pointer to Implementation) is and why it's used in C++.
questions.answer: The Pimpl idiom is a design pattern in C++ where the implementation details of a class are hidden behind a pointer (or smart pointer). This is done to achieve better encapsulation and separation between the public interface and private implementation details. It can also reduce compile-time dependencies and improve compilation times when implementation details change.

questions.title: What are smart pointers in C++? Explain the differences between std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr.
questions.answer:
Smart pointers are C++ objects that manage dynamic memory automatically, helping to avoid memory leaks.
std::unique_ptr is used when you want a single owner for the resource. It ensures that the resource is deleted when the unique_ptr goes out of scope.
std::shared_ptr allows multiple pointers to share ownership of a resource, and the resource is deleted when the last shared_ptr referencing it goes out of scope.

questions.title: What is an iterator in C++? Explain the difference between begin() and end() iterators.
questions.answer:
An iterator in C++ is an object that provides a way to access the elements of a container (like an array or a container from the Standard Library) in a sequential manner.
begin() returns an iterator pointing to the first element of the container.
end() returns an iterator pointing one past the last element of the container. It does not point to a valid element but is used to indicate the end of the sequence.

questions.title: What is the difference between const_iterator and iterator in C++ when working with containers?
questions.answer:
const_iterator is an iterator that points to constant elements within a container. It enforces that the elements it points to cannot be modified through the iterator.
iterator is an iterator that can be used to modify elements within a container. It allows both reading and writing of elements.

questions.title: Explain the differences between std::thread and std::async in C++ for achieving concurrency.
questions.answer:
std::thread is a low-level C++11 mechanism for creating and managing threads. It provides more control but requires explicit thread management, including joining or detaching threads.
std::async is a higher-level C++11 feature that allows for the creation of asynchronous tasks. It returns a future representing the result, and the system decides whether to run the task asynchronously or synchronously. It provides a simpler interface for concurrency tasks.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the explicit keyword in C++ constructors?
questions.answer: The explicit keyword is used to prevent implicit type conversions during object initialization. When applied to a constructor, it requires that the constructor be called explicitly with the appropriate argument types, reducing the risk of unexpected conversions.

questions.title: What is multiple inheritance in C++, and how is it different from single inheritance?
questions.answer: Multiple inheritance in C++ allows a class to inherit from more than one base class. Single inheritance, on the other hand, allows a class to inherit from only one base class. Multiple inheritance can lead to the diamond problem and requires careful design.
